title: W3C Web Applications Working Group-relevant MDN issues
description: Issue filed on MDN Web Docs related to pages attached to technologies developed by W3C Web Applications Working Group

items.content_html:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileReader/onerror

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

There is a comment in the sample code which I found confusing. why is it there

reader.abort(); // (...does this do anything useful in an onerror handler?)

Specific section or headline?

Sample Code

What did you expect to see?

The answer to that question in a comment

items.content_html:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ServiceWorkerRegistration

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The property updateViaCache is only available in the compatability table, but is nowhere described.

Specific section or headline?

updateViaCache

What did you expect to see?

An explaination on the property updateViaCache

Did you test this? If so, how?

items.content_html:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MouseEvent/ctrlKey

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

As explained already in the title, the key corresponding to 'ctrl' on Windows/Linux is "command" on Mac.

Specific section or headline?

The very first "Note" at the top of the page.

What did you expect to see?

"Command", instead of "Control"

MDN Content page report details

items.title: [uievents] Issue with "MouseEvent.ctrlKey": 'command' instead of 'control' for Mac keyboards

items.content_html:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Selection/setBaseAndExtent

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

If the argument anchorNode/focusNode is a text node, the corresponding offset is the index of the character.

Did you test this? If so, how?

var node = document.querySelector('.anything') //select an empty node!
node.textContent = "hello world!"
var tnode = node.childNodes[0]
var sel = window.getSelection()
sel.setBaseAndExtent(tnode, 0, tnode, 5) // this should select 'hello'
MDN Content page report details

items.title: [selection-api] Issue with "Selection.setBaseAndExtent()": behaviour on text nodes

items.content_html:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Clipboard/write

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The first example function setClipboard is incorrect, and reports an error on Chrome.

Specific section or headline?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Clipboard/write#example

What did you expect to see?

no error.
This article seems right: ClipboardItem JavaScript API
I made a little change to the example:

function setClipboard(text) {
  const type = 'text/plain';
  let blob = new Blob([text], {type});
  let data = [new ClipboardItem({ [type]: blob })];

  navigator.clipboard.write(data).then(function() {
    /* success */
  }, function(e) {
    /* failure */
  });
}

Did you test this? If so, how?

I tested on Chrome Version 91.0.4472.77 (Official Build) (64-bit)

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/clipboard/write
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Clipboard/write
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/clipboard/write/index.html
  • Last commit: e085698
  • Document last modified: 2021-05-29T04:16:39.000Z
items.title: [clipboard-apis] Issue with "Clipboard.write()": example setClipboard reports an error

items.content_html:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IndexedDB_API/Using_IndexedDB

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The code at "Updating an entry in the database" is adding a new entry instead of updating the existing one

Specific section or headline?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IndexedDB_API/Using_IndexedDB#updating_an_entry_in_the_database

What did you expect to see?

According to the ObjectStore put docs, to update an entry it is required to have a key as a second parameter, the current example calls put like this: var requestUpdate = objectStore.put(data); and it should be something like var requestUpdate = objectStore.put(data,"444-44-4444");

Did you test this? If so, how?

I tried to execute the example as is and it adds a new entry, adding the key as a second param updates the entry

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/indexeddb_api/using_indexeddb
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IndexedDB_API/Using_IndexedDB
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/indexeddb_api/using_indexeddb/index.html
  • Last commit: 12024ee
  • Document last modified: 2021-04-08T14:57:07.000Z
items.title: [IndexedDB-3] Issue with "Using IndexedDB": "Updating an entry in the database" example does not work

items.content_html:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IntersectionObserver/IntersectionObserver

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The description for rootMargin should indicate whether positive margins increase or decrease the threshold for intersection detection. This is particularly important because I can use margins to change the relative position of a box in CSS (e.g. I can move an element up 5 pixels by setting its top-margin to "-5px". The way the document describes this, it sounds like it functions more like CSS padding, such that setting the top value to "-5px" would decrease the size of the bounding box by 5px without moving the element.

Specific section or headline?

Parameters

What did you expect to see?

I'd like to see the description of how rootMargin works show how the option works, or at least describe its operations by stating more precisely which direction the bounding box grows (or moves?) when the value is positive vs when it is negative.

Did you test this? If so, how?

N/A

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/intersectionobserver/intersectionobserver

items.title: [intersection-observer] Issue with "IntersectionObserver.IntersectionObserver()": (short summary here please)

items.content_html:
Request type

  • Please close this issue, I accidentally submitted it without adding any details
  • New documentation
  • Correction or update

Details

According to W3C documentation on UI events, the main feature of focusin and focusout events is that the relatedTarget property is set to the corresponding counter-element in the FocusEvent argument of these two events, whereas with focus and blur events, the relatedTarget property is always null.

Shouldn't this important feature be mentioned in the docs of the corresponding MDN help pages?

Many people wonder why the relatedTarget property is always null when they listen to focus/blur, not knowing there are focusin/focusout events available.

I'd like to suggest to add this information (and "see also" references between these four events) to the corresponding MDN pages.

Related Pages on MDN

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/focusin_event
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/focusout_event
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/focus_event
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/blur_event
items.title: [uievents] Add description of  relatedTarget to focusin/focusout event
